content.title: Tracheostomy
content.summary: Surgical creation of an opening in the anterior trachea for long-term airway access, indicated for prolonged mechanical ventilation, airway obstruction, or pulmonary toilet
key_points: Surgical opening in anterior trachea creating stoma for direct airway access
Indications: prolonged mechanical ventilation (>14 days), upper airway obstruction, secretion management
PDT (percutaneous dilatational tracheostomy) vs open surgical tracheostomy
Benefits over prolonged ETT: patient comfort, decreased sedation, easier weaning, improved oral hygiene
Complications: bleeding, infection, tracheal stenosis, tracheoinnominate fistula
Decannulation when patient no longer needs artificial airway
Consider early tracheostomy (day 7-10) in patients likely to need prolonged ventilation

statement.text: Tracheostomy is a surgical procedure creating an opening (stoma) in the anterior trachea for direct airway access, bypassing the upper airway. It is indicated for patients requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation, those with upper airway obstruction, or patients needing improved access for pulmonary toilet. Percutaneous dilatational tracheostomy (PDT) can be performed at bedside in the ICU, while open surgical tracheostomy is done in the operating room. Decannulation is the goal when the underlying condition resolves.
statement.formal: Tracheostomy = Surgical tracheal stoma | Indications = Prolonged ventilation >7-14 days OR Airway obstruction OR Secretion management

explanation.intuition: An endotracheal tube through the mouth is uncomfortable and limits patient mobility, communication, and eating. For patients needing long-term mechanical ventilation, a tracheostomy creates a more comfortable, stable airway directly in the neck. This allows patients to be weaned from sedation, potentially speak (with special valves), and participate more in rehabilitation.
explanation.key_insight: The timing of tracheostomy remains debated. Early tracheostomy (day 7-10) may reduce sedation needs and ventilator days but doesn't clearly improve mortality. Patient selection matters more than timing - consider tracheostomy early if the patient is clearly going to need prolonged ventilation (e.g., high spinal cord injury, severe brain injury).
explanation.technical_details: PDT is performed at bedside using Seldinger technique with serial dilators under bronchoscopic guidance. Open surgical tracheostomy requires OR and provides better hemostasis. Tracheostomy tubes have inner cannulas (removable for cleaning), cuffs (for positive pressure ventilation), and come in various sizes and lengths. Speaking valves allow air to pass vocal cords on expiration.

definitions_glossary.tracheostomy: Surgical procedure creating opening (stoma) in anterior tracheal wall for airway access
definitions_glossary.tracheotomy: The incision itself (tracheostomy is the stoma/procedure)
definitions_glossary.percutaneous_dilatational_tracheostomy: Bedside procedure using dilators over guidewire inserted through cricothyroid/trachea
definitions_glossary.open_surgical_tracheostomy: Operating room procedure with direct surgical exposure of trachea
definitions_glossary.stoma: Artificial opening in body surface; tracheostomy stoma connects skin to trachea
definitions_glossary.decannulation: Removal of tracheostomy tube when no longer needed; stoma usually closes spontaneously
definitions_glossary.tracheal_stenosis: Narrowing of trachea from scarring; late complication of tracheostomy or prolonged intubation
definitions_glossary.tracheoinnominate_fistula: Rare catastrophic erosion between trachea and innominate artery; massive hemorrhage
definitions_glossary.speaking_valve: One-way valve allowing inhalation through trach but exhalation through vocal cords
definitions_glossary.cuffed_tube: Tracheostomy tube with inflatable balloon to seal airway for ventilation
definitions_glossary.fenestrated_tube: Tube with opening allowing air through vocal cords for speech
definitions_glossary.inner_cannula: Removable inner tube for cleaning without removing entire tracheostomy

pathophysiology.mechanism: Tracheostomy bypasses upper airway, providing direct tracheal access. This eliminates laryngeal injury from prolonged intubation, reduces dead space, decreases airway resistance, and allows easier suctioning. For obstructive lesions, it provides an airway below the obstruction.

indications.airway_obstruction: Upper airway tumor, bilateral vocal cord paralysis, severe angioedema
indications.secretion_management: Unable to clear secretions despite aggressive pulmonary toilet
indications.airway_protection: Severe neurological impairment with aspiration risk
indications.postoperative: After major head/neck surgery requiring airway control

open_surgical.advantages: Better hemostasis, visualization, suitable for difficult anatomy

post_procedure_care.cuff_management: Inflate for ventilation; deflate when tolerated for speech/swallowing
post_procedure_care.stoma_care: Keep clean and dry; dressing changes

complications.early: Bleeding, pneumothorax, false passage, tube displacement
complications.late: Tracheal stenosis, tracheomalacia, tracheoinnominate fistula, granulation tissue

decannulation.criteria: No ventilator requirement, able to protect airway, adequate cough, tolerate capping
decannulation.process: Downsize tube, cap trials, remove when tolerating 24-48h capped

definition.@value: Surgical procedure creating an opening in the anterior trachea for long-term direct airway access

skos.scopeNote: Covers indications, techniques (PDT and surgical), post-procedure care, and decannulation
skos.example: A 60-year-old with severe ARDS requiring mechanical ventilation for 3 weeks undergoes bedside PDT to facilitate weaning from sedation and ventilator liberation

learning_objectives: List indications for tracheostomy in ICU patients
Compare PDT vs open surgical tracheostomy approaches
Describe early and late complications of tracheostomy
Outline the decannulation process and criteria
clinical_pearls: Consider tracheostomy at day 7-10 if prolonged ventilation expected
PDT is preferred in most ICU patients - equivalent outcomes, lower infection rate
Tracheoinnominate fistula = massive hemorrhage - finger in stoma to tamponade, emergent surgery
Speaking valves require cuff deflation - patient must tolerate
Most stomas close within days after decannulation - rarely need surgical closure
Humidification essential - bypassed upper airway can't humidify inspired air
common_misconceptions: Tracheostomy is permanent (false - most patients are decannulated)
PDT is more dangerous than surgical (false - comparable safety in appropriate patients)
Tracheostomy prevents aspiration (false - reduces but doesn't eliminate aspiration risk)
